comments.commentBody:
The Republican party has become synonymous with greed, unAmerican and traitorous ideals and being easily corrupted.

It's not enough that Republicans win their elections through unsavory means such as gerrymandering, voter suppression and election interference by the Russians, the James Comeys, Wikileaks, SCOTUS and the list continues to grow.

Now, the Koch Brothers have sent out their puppet, Walker, to propagandize and rationalize the stifling of dissent to middle-class decimation. The GOP have created legislation in the last month to prevent Americans from protesting. You can't get more un-American than that.

Every time Scott Walker or Paul Ryan open their mouths, my first thought is what have the Koch brothers promised these guys, to make them willing to give up their reputations permanently and sell their souls. All that makes sense is a windfall of a hell of a lot of money. Ryan and Walker are so mired in greed, they have no idea that the average American would not be so easily corrupted. They are the weakest of Americans and are not cut from the same cloth as those who courageously fought for our freedoms.

Heartily agree.  However, the Scott Walkers of this country have long used the states rights argument to camouflage their real agendas regarding social, economic and cultural issues in the service of gaining, increasing and keeping power.  Having answered "God's calling" to run for President, Walker failed early (so early that Trump didn't get a chance to give him a nickname) and miserably (never polled > 1%) in his bid for the nomination, He returned his attention to the malgovernance of Wisconsin, where he perversely expanded Medicaid per the ACA but turned down the federal taxpayer dollars ($653 million) to pay for it.  In other words, he refused the return of federal tax dollars paid by Wisconsinites and is actually costing them state tax dollars in the form of the fees the state must pay the insurance companies who administer the Medicaid program.  He also failed to publicize federal court ordered changes in Wisconsin's egregious and unjust voter ID law by not funding the necessary effort to do so, preventing an estimated 300,000 of his citizens from voting.  Wisconsin clearly needs more, not less, monitoring and regulation on the part of the United States government until it rids itself of it's homegrown "criminal miscreant".

What a surprise, some balance from the NYT.  Now this country is not united, we have deep and abiding differences of opinion especially on what government should provide.  Considering this what better solution is there than a much smaller and less powerful federal government combined with states that create programs that their citizens desire and will pay for.  Limited federal government is good for all states.
Except for the ones that receive far more in federal aid than they contribute.

Mr. Walker has mistaken himself for America instead of a rather partisan and unpopular politician.

His anecdotes about death threats are not reason for the majority of citizens of America who did not vote for Mr. Trump to be blamed or to be told to "behave". Civil rights leaders and indeed protestors of all types have experienced these unfortunate actions. President Obama received many of these types threats from the very folks Walker is now championing.

There simply is no excuse for lawmakers to hide from citizens or refuse to listen to the concerns of voters or to call peaceful protest "intimidation".

Mr Walker is speaking as a partisan, not as a leader who listens to all of his constituents. When has he done other than "tout Republican ideology"? Please.

Reading the headline, I translated it to "Against the Will of the People, Republicans Must Stand Strong." There are millions of protesters and millions more who agree with them.
As for giving more power to the states, there are some areas where that's a bad idea. Civil rights is one of them--there need to be some federal standards to prevent a return to Jim Crow. Healthcare is another--if we send federal funds to the states, there should be some federal control over how that money is spent. And education--no kid should be denied a good science education because of some states' religious idea, or a rewrite of Civil War history.

How about returning authority to the people by not gerrymandering the state of Wisconsin. As a result of the gerrymandering we all know how that WI Democratic state legislative candidates received more votes in the November elections, yet they only won 39 of that state’s 99 districts.  It is still all about loyalty for the Republican party, rather than National or State interests.  If it was truly about the state rights, they'd let the people of the state have more say.  I write this knowing Walker won his re-vote, it still doesn't discount the gerrymandering.

It is mostly about who pays for healthcare, and while I don't want abortions to be illegal again, much greater restrictions are the state's responsibility.  The supreme court made up this right out of whole cloth for political purposes.  And there is no solution that works for all americans, not any more.
Exactly each state gets the policies that their citizens want and can make work.  And the poor today don't get taxed much, they have no money.

Governor Walker is ignoring the fact that most of the red states in this country benefit by getting more tax dollars back from the Federal Government than they send in in the first place.  If there were no Federal income tax (unpaid by many wealthy like Trump) there would be no military other than state National Guards or militias which can be called in to national service, but are not otherwise coordinated.  The poverty in states like Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, etc would be many times worse.  Even Texas would be a whole lot worse off if they weren't heavily populated by US military bases adding massive dollars to their states budgets.  We would be the Disunited States under his plan.

I'm glad the NYT is publishing op-ed pieces from the right as well as the left. I only wish they would find a contributor who wouldn't cloak the Republican agenda in state's rights. Take the author's position on drug testing welfare recipients: it has been declared unconstitutional in Michigan and saved little to no money (or even cost money) in other states, including Florida. If you want "small government," fine. But surely, forcing destitute citizens to hand over their urine in exchange for (quite literally) the bare essentials to continue living isn't "small government" at all.

Drug testing benefit recipients serves two functions:

It makes it harder and more demeaning to obtain the benefits.

It puts money into the hands of cronies who just happen to own labs that get government contracts to test applicants...

Walker describes a Wisconsin that does not exist. In November, the state Department of Administration reported the Walker administration will face a $693 million shortfall when drafting a biennial budget. Wisconsin roads and bridges are in dire need of repair, but there is no money, so state legislators (R's control the statehouse) ignore the problem. The world renowned University of Wisconsin System is at risk because of Walker policies. Faculty are leaving, and many are taking with them their research grants. Course offerings have been cut, while class sizes have increased. In the past two years, republicans tried to sell land with unique spring ponds. It took Trout Unlimited members and a Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reporter to expose the plan. Under Walker, the state DNR, once a model of quality scientific research, has been gutted of scientists. Walker appointed Cathy Stepp to lead the DNR. Stepp has no science background, and in fact, has no college degrees. She does have several memberships with home building associations, however. The state seems to have no plan to manage Chronic Wasting Disease within our deer population. Walker's administration has vilified public education, to the point that fewer students are selecting education as a major. Finally, the Walker redistricting plan was found to be unconstitutional because it takes away voting rights of minorities.
The state-of-the-State of Wisconsin is not as claimed by Walker.

Scott Walker wants to go back to the 1870's. No unions, workers working in unsafe and unhealthy conditions. Owners treating workers like serfs. If you couldn't afford to see a doctor, tough. Yes Scott, unions are the route of all evil. What a sad sad man.

If I hear another conservative politician say he--or she--is "fighting for the people" I do believe I'll lose my lunch. The GOP is for who it has always been for: the wealthy. Want to see what happens when conservatives gain the upper hand over an entire state? There's a place to look. It's called Kansas, where Sam Brownback and his party have wreaked economic and social havoc. Perhaps someone could take Mr. Walker on a tour of Kansas this weekend, while it's still there.

States rights are not something to be taken literally more that 200 years after the founding of our Country. For example, if taken literally there would never have been desegregation. Leave garbage collection and maintenance of the roads to city's and states. For the moral issues most of important to our nation we must move beyond the prejudices and parochialism of a minority of our nations population. Remember, most of America voted against Trump.
A top priority must be protecting the Democracy in America by weeding out all players who assisted Russia to derail the 2016 election.

Once again, our divisive governor trots out his fable about his amazing courage in facing down those low-life protesters (you know, teachers, health care workers, and more of their ilk). "I decided to take the high road". Really? He always leaves out the part where he and his advisors seriously considered bringing in outside agitators to turn public support against those opposed to his plans, and engaged in peaceful protest.

Governor Walker: Is this your let them eat cake moment?  Is your suggestion that the only one with valid representation are people who are registered and vote Republican? Ignoring your  liberals, Democrats and Independents constituents? That would mean I am being taxed without representation. That ideal is against the Constitution. Once elected you represent all the people not just the Republicans and lobbyists.

Richard:  So if the GOP philosophy of cutting taxes on the rich will create massive new jobs, why did the GOP members in Kansas just pass a tax increase bill of roughly a billion dollars to cover the huge hole in their budget - which good ol' Brownback vetoed?  Kansas is a prime case of how GOP governing is a massive failure.  But you keep drinking the Koolaid!!

Ann:  the republicans will only be able to dismiss the protesting left until the next election.  if the left comes out with energy and conviction, the right won't (can't) match it-- repealing the AFA isn't as passionate a matter as keeping the insurance that keeps loved ones alive...the GOP will be going down with the Trump ship in short order.
And out of the other side of its mouth the GOP speaks this week of stripping California of its right to regulate tailpipe emissions.

Mr. Walker, against whom should Republicans stand strong? (I realize that in phrasing my question this way I can be charged with effete elitism.) You and the Republican establishment you so admire are doing everything you can to keep the ninety nine percent powerless.

Tax cutting conservative economics doesn't work, in Wisconsin and elsewhere:

http://urbanmilwaukee.com/2016/01/22/data-wonk-has-walker-grown-wisconsi...

Governor Walker, I don't know what November election you are referring to, but the one that I witnessed in 2016 showed most emphatically that the electorate rejected Trump and the Republican agenda, by about 3 million votes. To now claim some kind of national mandate to shove that agenda down our throats is to dismiss the desires of the electorate at your peril. Counseling your Republican colleagues to ignore the majority does them no favors. 2018 is fast approaching. We will see whether you and your Republican friends are returned to your offices, or are sent home. There are millions of us that can't wait for our chance to turn you out.

Funny how states' rights disappear when the issue the states wish to pursue is in conflict with the Republican social agenda.  Take the recent announcement that the attorney general wishes to use the federal drug laws to thwart liberalization of marijuana laws in a half dozen states.   And, if you think that a repeal of Rowe vs Wade will turn the issue back to the states, think again!  The Republicans have no real interest in states' rights beyond pushing their reactionary agenda.

Ah yes, let's returning authority to the states. Best to look out for historical land borders! After all, when everyone is the country is dead from lack of foreign support and healthcare, what will America be besides a bunch of lines on a map?
